headline: French Onion Soup I
description: Thick slices of French bread are toasted in the oven and placed on top of each bowl of rich onion soup. Slices of Swiss cheese are melted over the toast.

video.description: See how to make a simple, comforting onion soup.
video.name: French Onion Soup I

name: French Onion Soup I

recipeInstructions.text: Melt butter or margarine in a 4 quart saucepan. Stir in sugar. Cook onions over medium heat for 10 minutes, or until golden brown.
Stir in flour until well blended with the onions and pan juices. Add water, wine, and beef broth; heat to boiling. Reduce heat to low. Cover soup, and simmer for 10 minutes.
Cut four 1 inch thick slices of bread from the loaf. Toast the bread slices at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) just until browned, about 10 minutes. Reserve the remaining bread to serve with the soup.

Ladle soup into four 12 ounce, oven-safe bowls. Place 1 slice toasted bread on top of the soup in each bowl. Fold Swiss cheese slices, and fit onto toasted bread slices. Place soup bowls on a cookie sheet for easier handling.
Bake at 425 degrees F (220 degrees C) for 10 minutes, or just until cheese is melted

review.reviewBody: I made just a few tweaks as suggested by previous viewers, it was delicious as I didn't want to vary too much from the original recipe. I used 2 cans beef consume instead of beef broth, used just a bit less than 1/2 cup butter, and sautéed the onions until caramelized. I also didn't have any swiss and was anxious to make it so I used a slice of provolone with some shredder mozzarella on top - worked great.

I have made this recipe before and found the wind to be overwhelming. This time I did two things I would decrease the line to about 2 tablespoons full and I added a chopped Charlotte these two changes improved the flavor at least for my taste. I only use Gerrer cheese and lots of it. I also used a thinner slice of the baguette.
No sugar, added a pot wine

This is the best onion soup recipe I’ve found. I’ve been using this recipe for years, the best I’ve had. I really like using a nice Australian Shiraz (and a glass for the cook), and adding a bit of sherry as well. (I may be a little generous with both.)
To make it Florentine onion soup, I add in just a little fresh, coarsely chopped spinach.
Love this recipe! Easy and delicious! Made it for Thanksgiving. Huge success!
Delicious soup. I used gruyere cheese and beef stock.
I had large onions and used three. I didn't really need that many.
It was a little bland! I would not use Swiss cheese again!
Delish, by far my favourite!
Delicious! Definitely worth the time. keep portions fairly small because it is very rich. I didn't have red wine so splashed in red wine vinegar.
It does need salt.

The onions take longer than 10 minutes to become golden (more like 30+) but let them cook. Drink a glass of the wine while the onions are cooking. I used a nice $10 Cabernet Sauvignon and it is wonderful!
My kids day it is better than any restaurant French onion soup they've ever had
Very easy and delicious.
I used 6 onions, 2 cans (unconcentrated) beef broth, and 1 cup water. Flavor was great!

With adjustments in the ingredients it was awesome. I used boxed beef broth and left out the water. Adjust liquid to taste and add a wine you would actually drink, not something you want to get rid of. Vary the cheese. Anyone can make this. Mine was a hit.
Delish!!! So easy. I did add some salt and went a little heavy on the wine. Family loved it!. I used a chunk of sourdough in each of the servings. They asked if I could make more :-)
I made this recipe exactly as is and it turned out perfect. My husband and I both loved it. This will definitely become a regular in our home.
I made one change; I added two beef bouillon cubes...read that without these the recipe would be too bland! My family loved it!!!
Love this recipe. Very tasty and easy to make
I used half cup of butter, and I couldn't find condensed beef broth so I added some beef bouillon cubes to regular beef broth. I followed recipe other than those slight changes. Delicious!

This was restaurant quality French onion soup. I use a carton of beef broth plus 1 can instead of the water and condensed broth. I toasted home made sourdough bread that I had on hand instead of the French bread and topped with Swiss and a touch of mozzarella that melted perfectly. This is a recipe to impress! Thank you
My favorite onion soup recipe using garlic Parmesan croutons and mozzarella cheese instead of french baguette and Swiss cheese. A real hit with all my family!!
The sliced onions were hard to eat with a spoon, chopped next time. I would use a bit less wine and more broth.

I have never even tasted french onion soup, so I depended on my family to rate it. It was easy, delicious...and filling! I took some suggestions of other ratees as well as a man I met in the grocery store. I used yellow onions rather than sweet, used 4 cans of beef broth rather than water and condensed soup, added a shake of Worcestershire sauce, and added about 1/2 tsp of salt. I used Gruyere cheese, which was a little thick and chewy, but still good. I loved it myself and was asked to make it every Wed night for dinner. :-)
It is very cheesy and I loved the way the wine gave it LOTS of flavor! Amazing recipe! "Keep it comin'!" ??, Yum,Yum,in my Tum!
perfect recipie

My first time making French onion soup, and it was easy and amazing! "Restaurant quality, or better" my husband raved. I did follow other reviewers suggestions, and I used provolone and mozzarella cheese, but I'll try Swiss next time. Excellent basic recipe! Thanks!

This would be a good recipe if it had any flavor. If you lose the water (or at least cut it in half, it will work). I reduced it for a while and added more beef broth, and it was OK. Even then it still needs some salt.

I've had some really high end ($$$$) onion soup, at well known restaurants, and I've gotta say, this was just as good. 
 
TIPS: 
- Take this recipe with a grain of salt; use it as a base. Taste and test throughout making it to add/subtract ingredients as YOU feel needed. 
- Use a mandeline to ensure the onions are cut very thin and consistent.
- Let it sit. Let it sit and stand for at least a few hours, to really infuse the flavours. 
- Brown the onions! That's where all of the deep flavour comes from.
My family loved this recipe.
The BEST onion soup we have ever had!!!!

This recipe wasn't difficult to make, however, it was very, very bland. In the future I would replace the water with more broth to give it flavor, possibly adding in a few beef bullion cubes as well. I did add in the wine this time although I think in the future it will be optional for me.
I loved this easy recipe. I couldn't believe it when I finished. My husband loved it more than the restaurant version. Yay me!! I'm so proud of myself! Thanks for the easy step-by-step instructions!!
Yum!

This recipe is the best! I only add more onions and a bit more butter, because I really like lots of onions! The flavour is perfect! I cube my I toasted baguette and cover with whatever shredded cheese I have before baking.
this was great! I used water and beef base instead of broth, about 2Tbsp or to taste. I didnt use the sugar, as the wine gave it enough sweetness. Used croutons because I didnt have the bread.
I loved this recipe an only changed it by using beef broth in stead of water and I used consomme soup(Campbells) to replace the beef broth.. was a deeply rich beef flavor to the base ..sooo yummy

MMM MMM, LIKE SO MUCH, MAKE AGAIN. LITTLE MORE SUGAR AND WINE TO TASTE.
WITHOUT GOOD FOOD, THERE IS NO LIFE
Made this as per the recipe. It wa awesome.My husband and I both enjoyed it immensely.
I made much better french onion soup, just was bland, not sure what I would change but just too boring and the onions need to be cook way longer
I liked this recipe. I have been searching for a good french onion soup. The only change I made was to use Chicken Broth instead of water.
As written didnt care for it..sorry....the wine was over powering ...I sauteed the onions for an hour only to lose the sweetness..yes wish I would have used white wine..and only 1/4 cup
Excellent!
I will use Valdalia onions next time to seeten it up a bit.
Fantastic!
this soup very good
This is a delicious and easy version of classic french onion soup!
Loved the recipe, tweaked it with a little red wine vinegar, and used gouda cheese...fabulous!!

Nothing wrong with this classic recipe, but two things I do: I think a key ingredient to french onion soup is thyme. I slowly brown/carmelize the onions over an extended period of time. This yields better flavors. 10 minutes will not do it.
A few other 'ideas'? I'm into spicy foods and will often throw a couple of bird's eye peppers or similar. On occasion, I'll add bacon for a bit of a Canadian twist. But if you do, do so after you've finished cooking the soup. Otherwise, it will tend to cook the bacon flavor right out and simply leave the soup just a bit saltier than it already it was.
Finally, consider making an extra effort on the bread. Cut or break into appropriate sized pieces and throw into a bag with a bit of olive oil, thyme, pepper, etc; and shake it like a polaroid picture. Then bake in oven until dry and crunchy. Keep these on hand for the next few days to throw into your soup as required.
One of the best I have tasted.
Easy and tasty! I love this recipe!

This was DELICIOUS!!! Just as good if not better as any I have had at restaurants. I followed the advice of carmelizing the onions for longer, about 25 minutes and it was perfect. My boyfriend loved it too!

This is the first time I tried french onion soup because I try it everywhere and I was certain mine wouldn't compare. I was wrong. I used this recipe with a few changes and it was just as good if not better than restaurant. I caramelized the onion first, and added beef boullion to the water. I also gave it a splash of garlic powder, salt, and worstechire (whatev) sauce. It was delicious and simple!

I think this is my 2nd time reviewing this because I just made this soup again yesterday and it knocked my socks off. The only change I made was a bit less wine. I can't wait to make it for a potluck because people will be blown away. So easy, so delicious. Best ever and I've had TONS of french onion soup.

Phenomenal! I just returned Paris where my Christmas Eve dinner was a comforting bowl of authentic French onion soup. I had made this recipe years ago (an ex-bf engulfed it), and decided to try it again due to my Parisian nostalgia. I tweaked the recipe a little: substituted one quart of beef broth for the water and broth called and used olive oil instead of butter. It came out even better than I remembered!
It's a good recipe; can't say great.
This was awesome! One of the best french onion soups I've had in a long time. I used chicken broth instead of beef and pinot grigio instead of redwine. My husband licked his plate clean!

Delicious! Used brown sugar instead of white, croutons instead of bread, and added a few dashes of Worcestershire, salt, pepper, and thyme as recommended by some other reviewers. Also threw in some thinly-sliced mushrooms. Husband said it was the best soup he'd ever tasted, and has even requested that I make it for our Christmas dinner at HIS family's house! Success! :)
Not good.
the best french onion soup ever!!!! Easy to make and sooooo good!!!!
First attempt at it.....and I loved it! I'm going to keep this one!
This was the best french onion soup I have made! tried many, I did add extra onions, just cause we like some in every bite, It was fantastic

Loved it! Changes: 3 cups of yellow onions, carmelize and you don't need any sugar, used vegetable broth, toasted baguette slices in toaster, topped floating toast with grated swiss - melted well without the oven. Only used 1 cup of water and it was perfect for 2 large servings.
I found that using a packet of brown beef gravy mix works well instead of beef bullion. Use one or two packages and then water to get the right consistency.

Great café quality and taste! However, I do have a few tweaks... 
1. Use two 10.5 ounce cans of beef consommé instead of condensed broth. It's easier to find in the stores and will get rid of that water and wine taste others have complained about. Do be sure to add the water and wine as directed though, as with consommé, it is really needed. 
2. Cook the onions on medium heat for a good 40 minutes. 
3. Simmer the soup for at least 20 minutes, if not more. 
4. Toast eight slices of bread (so as to put two in each bowl) for 5 minutes, flip them, and toast the other side for another 5 minutes. 
5. Mozarella works better than Swiss, and only use half of what the recipe calls for. 
6. On an upper rack, broil the bowls for three minutes (or until it is browned) on a low temperature instead of baking.
All in all, this is a great recipe that was well worth the tears.

This recipe is fabulous! 
The only problem I had was that it's very hard to find condensed broth, so I added 3-5 organic beef bullion cubes ( it depends on who I cook for) to the broth. I have read other reviews, and they say to skip adding the water. That's another option as well, but I prefer adding the bullion cubes instead. I also added one whole stick of butter (salted or unsalted ...that's up to you) and I sauteed the onions longer as in 30 minutes or so.  Also, if you don't have french breach, any kind of bread will do depending on what you or your audience will like.  All in all, this is a great recipe and very easy to make!  
PS... I soak my onions in cold water so that they don't make me cry too much!  
(Peel before soaking!) :}

Yummm! I just made this for the first time and it is delicious! I made a few changes: 1/2 butter, 2 yellow onions which made about 4 cups when sliced, I browned them slowly as other reviews said (well worth the time!). Since I don't eat beef I used 4 tsp Better than Bouillon Vegetable paste dissolved in 4 cups of boiling water. Added some minced garlic before the flour and used 2 tbsp whole wheat flour. Didnt have red wine so I used white with a tbsp Worcestershire sc. Added croutons and baked...sooo good! Will make again
added garlic and more sugar, salt and pepper and some cayenne

I have made this over two dozen times and it is great, but I have a few tweaks. First, use 5 tbsp of butter rather than 4. Next, use 3 full cups of water. Next, use a full cup of red wine. Finally, use French bread rather than a baguette and cut your slices thick so that the cheese does not dip into the soup. I also find that 10 minutes for the cheese to melt is way too long. By that time the cheese has been bubbling for a few minutes already. 5-8 minutes is a better amount of time, depending on how bubbly you want your cheese. As a side note, French bread is much better than Italian bread because French bread is drier, which is good for this. I also slice a few thinner pieces of bread for dipping. Great recipe.

Very happy with recipe. As there are 6 different types of red wine; I used a Shiraz (or Shirah). It has the deepest flavor of the reds; not sweet at all. I used 4 vidalia onions and no flour. I pressure canned the soup after I tried it. It took over an hour for the onions to turn brown, so be warned. I didn't make the crouton or cheese, I'm allergic to milk. Followed the recipe to a T; except for the flour. Very impressed, thanks for posting!
Very very good.

It's OK but the onions need to caramelize for at least 45 minutes to bring out the flavour and sugars. Don't worry if they burn some. As a matter of fact - let them. Much Much better this way. And never Red wine! The tannins kill all the sweetness we worked so hard to bring out. White wine, a bit of congnac but not red wine.
the recipe was very easy, but the end result was lacking in rich flavor.

This recipe is absolutely amazing. I used 3 bullion cubes - along with 3 cups of water - to make by beef broth instead of buying the canned beef broth (it end up being the same thing, really). I used a nice cab sauv as my red wine. OMGoodness!! It was restaurant quality; even my guests said so!!
absolutely fantastic - may be be the best onion soup we've ever had! Gets extra points for how easy it is to make - we will make this over and over again...

First thing is just ten minutes of cooking the onions is not near long enough, you need to cook the onions over a medium heat until the are golden brown (caramelized), this can take awhile, but it is what gives flavor to the onions. I added some minced garlic right before adding the flour. I also cooked my onions in a mixture of bacon grease and butter.
I bought a generic beef broth since I had no fresh left in my freezer...what a mistake to buy a big store's generic broth, I actually tasted it before using it and it pretty much tasted like water. So i added a cube of beef bouillon and a good dash of Worcestershire sauce. I used only the broth, if I added water it would really be lacking flavor. 
Also the bread at the end needs to be quickly broiled until golden brown on low under the broiler and not baked for another ten minutes, or it gets mushy. 
If I make again I'll only use some fresh beef broth or beef consume. My onions were great all by themselves, I used fresh thyme from the garden to spice them. I had some yellow, some red and some sweet.

This is actually the 1 out of 2 things my husband will cook. And it is delicious. So much flavor, the onions are so tender and easy to eat. The cheese he puts on it can be a little much, it can somtimes get hard to swallow a big wad of melted cheese but that doesn't deter me from enjoying this! Absolutely delicious and one of our favorites!

No Flavor. Too much water I think. It definitely was no Jason's Deli French Onion soup. I tried to add some salt. It was a shame too because my onions were fantastic.

I may have done something wrong in the recipe. I hate to say this about it because I do appreciate the submissions from all of users. Sorry.
excellent!!!
Outstanding! Even the kids liked it...
Very good!

This was yummy! I used a little less water just because I prefer more "meaty" soup. I also only used 3 TBSP of butter. I also happened to have some sweet italian turkey sausage that I needed to use up. I cooked the links while the onions were cooking, crumbled them up and added them to the soup at the end. I let the sausage flavor soak into the soup on the stove for a few minutes. It was really good and made a more hearty meal. Also instead of putting the bowls in the oven at the end, I just put the bread with swiss cheese in the oven alone for a few minutes and then placed the bread slices on top of the soup before eating. But that was just because I wasn't positive if my bowls were oven proof or not.

This onion soup was really delicious! I made it for my parents on Valentine's day and they both said it was better than any french onion soup they ever tasted. I had never eaten french onion soup before and I loved it. It was a bit heavy though and I got full really quickly. I followed the directions that was given and it came out perfect. You really have to reduce the soup for a long time to get the flavor stronger. I'm definitely going to make this again!

This onion soup was really delicious! I made it for my parents on Valentine's day and they both said it was better than any french onion soup they ever tasted. I had never eaten french onion soup before and I loved it. It was a bit heavy though and I got full really quickly. I followed the directions that was given and it came out perfect. You really have to reduce the soup for a long time to get the flavor stronger. I'm definitely going to make this again!

I'm sure this recipe is great when you realize that your beef broth isn't condensed before you add all the water and sit down to eat it...I was really looking forward to it, but, I think the recipe should be altered, as the majority of pantries don't have condensed broth in them

I'm not really a fan of French onion soup but I saw a program on the Food Network where they served it and was then totally craving it! This recipe is so simple yet it has a ton of flavor! Because of the reviews, I made a few minor changes... I used a tablespoon of sugar to make it a little more sweet, and used more beef broth to substitute the water. Great recipe, and will definitely make again!

Maybe the broth I used was not strong enough, but I found this soup to be bland, and the red wine made it a rather unappealing color. I have made French Onion soup before, and it always came out tastier than this particular recipe.

My picky teenage son actually said "If I thought we were having pizza and I found out we were having this instead, I wouldn't mind at all." I didn't change a single thing on this recipe. As is, it is better than anything I've had in a French restaurant.

I doubled the amount, used yellow onions 1 or 2 white onions -NOT sweet onlions- It took quite a bit longer to brown the onions. Try at a high to medium heat, added Cabernet Sauvignon red wine by Clos Du Bois (very reasonable cost) I used beef broth by Campbells soup and Aujus in a generic gravy packet which really spruced it up. I bought FRENCH GARLIC CROUTONS baged in the store Mozerella was my choice of cheese (whole milk Frigo) and nuked it for 1 min. That made it awesome as heck!
Great soup! Cook onions slowly for great flavor. We added some garlic, per a suggestion below. Turned out very good.
Good recipe!

Gave 3 stars... I made first steps accordingling..... And very bland, not enough beef flavor.... I added sherry cooking wine, worchstier sauce... and still i little bland on beef.... I thought I had beef buillon, but added a packackage of lipton onion soup mix and 1 chicken buillon..... This by far was the best french onion soup ever...... I gave 3 stars ause the basics were there, but not the flavor!!!!
easy peasy and delish!
I followed other comments and subbed out the water for beef broth and added a bit of dried thyme at the very end. We all loved this and it will become a winter staple for my family.

Fantastic! This soup tasted like restaurant quality. Onions need much longer than 10 minutes to carmelize. Mine took at least 25 minutes. I used 2 tsp of sugar to add to the sweetness and I also used vidalia onions. You could taste the wine but it wasn't overbearing. I topped with provolone as I didn't have the swiss on hand and it was just as good. Great recipe!

I love French Onion Soup & had everything for this on hand. Do take the suggestions and add more butter, garlic, & worchestershire, but I did not care for the thyme & I only added 1/2tsp. GREAT recipe thank for sharing!!
Fantastic!!!!
So easy and sooo good! I used 3 sweet onions and left out the wine but it was still excellent. I will make this again soon. Thanks for posting!
